results.content_html: Pace seems to ramp up quickly through the Bootstrap and jQuery sections so you'll find you'll have to go back through lessons to work out what's going on

results.content:
First three sections are good. Easy to understand explanations of HTML/CSS. However the last 2 sections throw a number of assumptions on the student's capabilities. 
Also, and I believe this to be because of how old the course is, some of the code doesn't work when typing it out exactly.
Not to mention that two videos are the wrong way round in the last section.
results.content_html:
First three sections are good. Easy to understand explanations of HTML/CSS. However the last 2 sections throw a number of assumptions on the student's capabilities.
Also, and I believe this to be because of how old the course is, some of the code doesn't work when typing it out exactly.
Not to mention that two videos are the wrong way round in the last section.

results.content:
All of these videos pretty much done in one go, which is a bad thing. After all nobody wants to watch constant typos being made or moments of awkward silence. That's why such thing as editing exists.
Just to name a few other issues: incorrect naming of some chapters ("20. Adding an iFrame" where iFrame is not even mentioned or "44. Background Images" where this guy talks about borders instead), Adobe Dreamweaver and it's functionality constantly brought up for basically no reason, some of the used techniques are outdated (pt instead of px or em/rem), the ugly logo is constantly hovering over the screen...

So overall it's quite basic stuff, poorly structured and badly produced.
Not the worst course for beginners, but definitely not among the best or even good ones in my opinion.
results.content_html:
All of these videos pretty much done in one go, which is a bad thing. After all nobody wants to watch constant typos being made or moments of awkward silence. That's why such thing as editing exists.
Just to name a few other issues: incorrect naming of some chapters ("20. Adding an iFrame" where iFrame is not even mentioned or "44. Background Images" where this guy talks about borders instead), Adobe Dreamweaver and it's functionality constantly brought up for basically no reason, some of the used techniques are outdated (pt instead of px or em/rem), the ugly logo is constantly hovering over the screen...

So overall it's quite basic stuff, poorly structured and badly produced.
Not the worst course for beginners, but definitely not among the best or even good ones in my opinion.
